text: Targeted disruption of the <extra_id_0> MyD88 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene results in loss of IL-1 - and <extra_id_0> IL-18 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated function .

<extra_id_0> MyD88 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , originally isolated as a myeloid differentiation primary response gene , is shown to act as an adaptor in interleukin-1 ( IL-1 ) signaling by interacting with both the IL-1 receptor complex and IL-1 receptor - associated kinase ( IRAK ) .

Mice generated by gene targeting to lack <extra_id_0> MyD88 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> have defects in T cell proliferation as well as induction of acute phase proteins and cytokines in response to IL-1 .
Increases in interferon-gamma production and natural killer cell activity in response to <extra_id_0> IL-18 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are abrogated .
In vivo Th1 response is also impaired .

Furthermore , <extra_id_0> IL-18 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced activation of NF-kappaB and c-Jun N-terminal kinase ( JNK ) is blocked in <extra_id_0> MyD88 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - / - Th1-developing cells .

Taken together , these results demonstrate that <extra_id_0> MyD88 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a critical component in the signaling cascade that is mediated by IL-1 receptor as well as <extra_id_0> IL-18 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> receptor .
